main.description:
Welcome to your Zettelkasten!

Zettelkasten is German for 'note box'. It is a note-taking technique where you write short notes containing one idea, and then link them to connected ideas.

For a great discussion of why Zettelkasten is more powerful than linear (notebook) or hierarchical notetaking, see David Clear's introductory [article](https://writingcooperative.com/zettelkasten-how-one-german-scholar-was-so-freakishly-productive-997e4e0ca125) on the subject.

This is the 'homepage' of your Zettelkasten, and you can edit this note or add other notes with the toolbar above.

Documentation

* [[20200921-113652]]
* [[20200921-113337]]
* [[20200921-112831]]
* [[20200921-115100]]

20200921-112831.description:
To link to other notes, you can use wiki-link syntax. This is the ID of a note (up there in the URL) surrounded in double square brackets like this:

`[[20200921-112831]]`

To help you out, when you start typing `[[a search term` some autocomplete options will pop up, searching the titles, descriptions and IDs of each note.

If you want to try it out, click the pencil icon to edit, and type `[[` and type 'zettelkasten' and you should see the homepage note come up.

<!-- Type the `[[` without backticks, which tell Markdown to ignore the format -->

You can still use markdown style links like `[link text](http://example.com)` to link to other websites.

20200921-113337.description:
All of your notes are written in [Github Flavoured Markdown](https://docs.github.com/en/github/writing-on-github/basic-writing-and-formatting-syntax).

Markdown is basically a simple extension to plain text that formats things like this:

```
* this
* list
```

into this:

* this
* list

among many other functions.

There are several extensions to Markdown which you can use:

* Wikilink syntax for linking between notes ([[20200921-112831]]).
* [[20201012-121348]] (LaTeX syntax)
* [[20201012-070239]]

20200921-114704.description:
In a hierarchical note taking program like [Cherrytree](https://www.giuspen.com/cherrytree/), you have to impose a pre-planned hierarchy on your notes before writing them. Often times, the structure you plan tends to lead to some sections being a thousand words long while others are tiny. Restructuring your notes is difficult and tedious, and it's hard to judge when you need to do so.

In Zettelkasten, you can reorganise your notes frictionlessly by just changing a link or splitting one note into two. As each note is small to begin with, it's easy to see when to split them (principle of atomicity), and having more notes does not decrease ease of use.

20200921-114801.description:
When you write in a notebook, often ideas connect in complex ways which the medium of a notebook cannot easily express. For instance, you may have an idea on page 47 that builds on another on page 22. To benefit from this link you would need to reread your notebook to find it, and then write a page number as a reference, which is quite clunky.

In a hierarchical note taking program, often times ideas in different sections are linked, which is not easily accounted for.

In Zettelkasten, the structure naturally arises to suit your needs. You may find yourself writing notes that link to a number of other notes, as portals into a specific topic. You may find you need to link ideas in different domains as well, and this can be accomplished through the one inter-card linking mechanism.

20200921-115100.description:
You can use notes to represent anything. Here is a list of uses I have found for them:

* Crazy ideas. This forces you to fully form your idea and allows you to revisit it or link it to other ideas later.
* Overviews of concepts. Think Wikipedia articles, but far shorter and only describing what is relevant to your needs. If you use a notebook in classes, you can summarise them into notes here to grow your Zettelkasten.
* Hub notes. These are a common pattern for organising your notes by creating notes which link to a number of notes on a certain topic.
* Annotated bibliographical entries. Add a citation and some key points, and when you write a note elsewhere you can cite your bibliographical notes.
* Blog post ideas
* Networking. Never tried this though.
* Tutorials. If you always forget how to install X on Y, dump it here!
* Personal reflection

20201011-064746.content: Write a tutorial explaining how monads are isomorphic to burritos in the category of food

20201012-121348.description:
You can use LaTeX syntax for inline and block level equations. They must be delimited by `$$double dollar signs$$`.

When they stand on their own line they are block level like below, otherwise they are inline ($$a = b$$).

$$\hat{x}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n x_i$$

The math renderer is dynamically loaded when needed.

20201012-070239.description:
Syntax highlighting is enabled for a subset of languages: * JavaScript (with JSX xor TypeScript) ```jsx const c = (a, b) =>
{a}
; while (true) console.log(c(1,1)); ``` * Python ```py def f(x): return x**2 - 2*x + 1 g = lambda x: (x-1)**2 assert(f(2) == g(2)) ``` The exact list of languages currently supported via [Prism.js](https://prismjs.com/) is: markup (HTML/XML), CSS, JS, C, C++, Haskell, $$\LaTeX$$, PureScript, Python, JSX, TypeScript. Feel free to request more languages via the [issue tracker](https://github.com/OliverBalfour/Mirror/issues) as it is trivial to add more.
